title: Spyware, Inc.
content:
Sorry for the absence of me (even though NO ONE NOTICED), but I've got some spyware. Now this makes me think - who invented this? Was Kazaa the first? Was Real the major distributor? Is this all a conspiracy by the anti-virus companies? Does it all lead back to the Pope, as in the whole "New Coke Formula" mishap? So many questions.------------------------------------

title: Re: Spyware, Inc.
content: No idea what was first. But they sure are really annoying. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-garg.gif[/img] You hear in your mind: GAAARRRRRGG!

title: Why Spare.
content:
I have no problems with spyware nowadays... web browsers with effective popup blockers (Firefox, Opera and XP's SP2 IE6 are in use across my network), and freeware programs like Spybot, SpySweeper and Microsoft AntiSpyware make sure of that.

My guess as to spyware's origin involved pr0n... all those topsites and popups and such that made themselves prominent across Warez back in the day, and the random dialers and other junk that would randomly appear. I really have no idea, though, so don't quote me on that (unless I happen to be correct).Cave assectatorem Ductoris Alacris

"You are so afraid to live--so afraid of life itself--that you've given up the very nature of your being in trade for security."
-CWG Book 3, Neale Donald Walsh

[url=http://jimsoft.spatang.com/]JimSoft Lair[/url]

title: Re: Why Spare.
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]My guess as to spyware's origin involved pr0n...[hr][/quote]
It's surprising just how many things have origins in porn. VHS succeeding over Betamax, DVD camera angles - the list goes on.
My [url=http://kevan.org/brain.cgi?grafix5000]MindBending Power[/url] is 5.43 points.
Possibly the [url=http://legion.gibbering.net/misterx/troutwar.php?s=grafix5000]funniest thing[/url] on the interweb.

content:
